transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.text: Hi Sydney, thanks so much for taking the time to speak with me today. My name is Emily, and I'm part of the customer insights team here at iRobot. We really appreciate you sharing your feedback with us online, and we'd love to delve a little deeper into your experience with the Roomba 694.

transcript.speaker: Sydney
transcript.text: Hey Emily, no problem. Happy to chat. I figured if I'm going to write a review, I should be willing to talk about it too, right?

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.text: Exactly! And we truly value all feedback, both positive and critical, as it helps us understand our products better and, ultimately, improve them. Just to set expectations, this call should take about 30 minutes, and we'll just be talking through your experience, no right or wrong answers. Does that sound okay?

transcript.speaker: Sydney
transcript.text: Yeah, 30 minutes works for me.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.text: Great. So, you mentioned in your review that you and your partner were curious about smart home tech but hesitant to dive in. Can you tell me a little more about what specifically drew you to the Roomba 694 as that "entry point" into automated cleaning? What was your initial thinking behind that purchase?

transcript.speaker: Sydney
transcript.text: Hmm, that's a good question. I guess... we had been thinking about getting *some* kind of robot vacuum for a while. Our townhouse, it's not huge, but it's three levels, and the main floor, which is where we spend most of our time – living room, kitchen, dining – it's all hard surfaces, hardwood and tile. And honestly, sweeping just feels like a chore, you know? Just the daily dust, crumbs from cooking... it adds up. I'm a UX designer, so I'm always looking for ways to optimize tasks, make things more efficient. And the idea of setting it and forgetting it, coming home to cleaner floors, was really appealing.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.text: I completely understand that desire for efficiency. And what about the 694 specifically? Were you looking at other models or brands at the time?

transcript.speaker: Sydney
transcript.text: Yeah, we did a bit of research, mostly online reviews, articles. The Roomba brand is just so... synonymous with robot vacuums, right? It's the one everyone knows. And the 694 seemed like a good price point for an *introduction*. It wasn't the cheapest thing out there, but it also wasn't the super high-end one with all the mapping and auto-empty bins. We figured, "Let's dip our toes in with something that seems reliable but isn't a huge investment." We weren't ready to drop a grand on a vacuum we weren't sure we'd even like.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.text: That makes a lot of sense, starting with a known brand at an accessible price. And you've had it for about five months now. Looking back, what aspects of the Roomba 694 have actually met or even exceeded those initial expectations you had?

transcript.speaker: Sydney
transcript.text: Oh, for sure, it *does* clean. Like, when it actually runs without getting stuck, the floors *do* feel cleaner. You see the dustbin after, and it's surprising how much stuff it picks up that you didn't even realize was there. Hair, dust, little bits of crumbs. It definitely maintains a baseline level of tidiness, which is what we wanted. And the app scheduling, that's genuinely good. Being able to just set it to run while we're out, that's the core convenience factor that works. Coming home to visibly tidier common areas is nice. And the dustbin is super easy to just pop out and empty, which is a small but appreciated design detail.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.text: So the core function of cleaning and the convenience of scheduling are definitely hitting the mark. That's great to hear. You also mentioned, however, that the list of frustrations is long. Let's dig into that a bit. Your biggest issue, you wrote, was the "completely random navigation." Can you tell me more about how that impacts your daily life and your perception of the product?

transcript.speaker: Sydney
transcript.text: Ugh, the navigation. It's... it's just so frustrating. As a UX designer, I think about efficient paths, logical flows, right? This thing has absolutely none of that. It just bumps around. It'll clean one section of the kitchen five, six times and then completely ignore the dining room that's literally right next to it. Or it'll do half the living room and then wander off. It feels less like a "smart" robot and more like a drunk Roomba, just aimlessly bumping into things. It means I can't trust it to actually clean *all* the areas I want it to. I've walked in after a run and seen huge, visibly dusty patches it just completely missed.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.text: That sounds incredibly inefficient and definitely not what you'd expect from a "smart" device. So, it's not just about missing spots, but the *randomness* makes you lose confidence in its ability to do the job thoroughly.

transcript.speaker: Sydney
transcript.text: Exactly. It's the unpredictability. If I knew it would always clean the kitchen, then the living room, even if it took a weird path, that'd be one thing. But I just don't know what it's going to do. It feels like a gamble every time. And for the price, I really expected something with *some* semblance of logic.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.text: I hear you. You also highlighted its "propensity to get stuck" as perhaps the most annoying drawback. Could you walk me through a typical scenario of it getting stuck? What kind of items does it get caught on most frequently in your townhouse?

transcript.speaker: Sydney
transcript.text: Oh, God, the getting stuck. It averages at least one "Roomba stuck" notification per cleaning cycle, sometimes more. It's almost guaranteed. We have a moderately cluttered townhouse, as I said, but it's not like a hoarder's den. We have dining chairs – it loves to wedge itself under the narrow gaps of the chair legs. Like, it'll try to go under, realize it can't, but then just keeps pushing until it's properly stuck. And our area rugs? They have fringe, and it *always* gets tangled in the fringe. Every. Single. Time. Then there's this low-profile floor vent, totally flush with the floor, but it tries to climb it anyway and just gets hung up.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.text: So it's not just a specific type of obstacle, but a variety of common household items that present a challenge. And when it gets stuck, what's your typical routine? How does that disrupt your day or evening?

transcript.speaker: Sydney
transcript.text: It's awful. It usually happens when we're trying to relax after work, or sometimes if I'm trying to concentrate on something. My phone will buzz with the "Roomba stuck" notification. So then I have to get up, go find it – and sometimes it's really wedged in there. Like, I have to pull a chair out to get it. Then I have to untangle whatever hair or rug fringe is wrapped around its brushes, which is a fiddly task itself. It completely breaks the "set it and forget it" promise. It turns into "set it, *wait* for it to get stuck, then go rescue it, untangle it, and restart it." It makes the whole point of automation moot. I might as well just sweep myself sometimes, because I'm spending almost as much time intervening.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.text: That sounds incredibly frustrating, especially for someone who values efficiency and convenience. It really undermines the core benefit, as you said. You also mentioned mediocre battery life and high noise levels. How do those two factors affect your use of the Roomba?

transcript.speaker: Sydney
transcript.text: The battery life, yeah. It usually covers about two-thirds of our main floor, which, you know, isn't huge. So it rarely finishes a full cycle before needing to recharge. And then, it doesn't always find its way back to the charger efficiently. We'll often find it just dead in a random corner, not even close to its home base. So then it just sits there until one of us notices it and takes it back. As for noise, it's... it's like a regular vacuum cleaner. Not super quiet at all. We definitely can't run it if we're working from home or trying to watch TV. So it's mostly relegated to running when we're out, but even then, if we come home and it's still running, it's pretty disruptive.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.text: So, the noise level restricts *when* you can use it, and the battery life and docking issues often mean it doesn't complete its job even when it is running. All these factors seem to contribute to a feeling of the Roomba being less "smart" and more like a high-maintenance appliance.

transcript.speaker: Sydney
transcript.text: Exactly. It feels like it requires more management than it saves.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.text: Thinking about your overall experience over these five months, you concluded that it's a "very basic robot vacuum with significant compromises" that doesn't "quite justify its price tag." Could you elaborate on that price/value perception? What, for the price you paid, would you have expected it to do better or differently?

transcript.speaker: Sydney
transcript.text: Well, considering my income and what I'm willing to spend on tech that genuinely improves my life, this wasn't an insignificant purchase. I think we paid around $250, maybe $270? For that, I would have expected a little more intelligence. At a minimum, some kind of basic, logical cleaning pattern. Not full-on mapping, but just... not completely random. If it could clean in straight lines, or systematically cover sections, that would already be a huge improvement. And better obstacle avoidance! It's advertised as a robot vacuum. Robots should be able to navigate a room without constantly getting stuck on super common household items. That's fundamental, honestly. The constant need for rescue is the biggest detractor from its value proposition.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.text: It sounds like "self-sufficiency" is a key element that's missing for you. If those frustrations around navigation and getting stuck were significantly reduced, do you think your perception of its value would change?

transcript.speaker: Sydney
transcript.text: Oh, absolutely. If it could reliably clean the main floor without needing me to intervene even once, and if it covered the whole area reasonably well, then yes, I think it would totally justify the price. That's the dream, right? The "set it and forget it" that it promises. Right now, it feels like I'm paying for a promise that's only partially delivered.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.text: That's a very clear distinction. As a UX designer, you're uniquely positioned to offer insights into product improvement. Beyond what we've discussed, do you have any specific suggestions for improvements or features that would make the Roomba 694, or an entry-level robot vacuum in general, a much better product for someone like yourself?

transcript.speaker: Sydney
transcript.text: Hmm, okay. So, from a UX perspective, obviously, the navigation is paramount. Even a basic 'bounce-and-go' algorithm could be improved by adding, I don't know, a 'wall-following' mode or 'spiral' mode for open areas. Just something to give it some structure. For obstacle avoidance, maybe better sensors for low-lying objects or a softer touch when it bumps into things to prevent wedging. And for the rug fringe, could it detect that and lift its brushes slightly, or reverse course more decisively? Also, if the battery is going to be mediocre, then it *really* needs to be better at finding its way home. Maybe a stronger signal from the base, or some kind of beacon? And the brush cleaning... it's such a pain. Is there a way to design brushes that tangle less, or are easier to detangle, maybe with quick-release ends or a tool built into the unit itself? Right now, it's just a fiddly mess of hair and dust.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.text: Those are really actionable suggestions, Sydney, especially thinking about specific sensor behaviors and brush design. We appreciate you sharing those. Just one more question before we wrap up: if you were talking to a friend or colleague who was considering buying a robot vacuum, based on your experience with the 694, how likely would you be to recommend it on a scale of 1 to 10, where 1 is "definitely not" and 10 is "absolutely"? And why?

transcript.speaker: Sydney
transcript.text: Oh, man. I'd probably give it a... honestly, a 4. Maybe a 5 if I was feeling generous.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.text: Okay, a 4 or 5. And what are the key reasons for that rating?

transcript.speaker: Sydney
transcript.text: It's just too inconsistent. I'd tell them, "Look, it *does* clean, and the app scheduling is good." Those are the positives. But then I'd immediately tell them about the random navigation, how it misses huge sections, and the constant getting stuck. I'd tell them to consider if they want to spend their time rescuing a robot vacuum. For someone who just wants *some* help with daily dust and has a perfectly clear, open floor plan, maybe it's fine. But for anyone with even a moderately typical home, it's just not self-sufficient enough. I'd probably advise them to save up for a model with actual mapping capabilities, or at least better obstacle avoidance, or just stick to a traditional vacuum for now. The compromises are just too significant for the convenience it *sometimes* offers.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.text: That's very clear feedback, Sydney, and truly valuable for us. Thank you for being so candid and for sharing your insights, especially from your perspective as a UX designer. It gives us a lot to think about as we continue to develop our products. We really appreciate your time today.

transcript.speaker: Sydney
transcript.text: No problem, Emily. Thanks for listening. I hope it helps.

transcript.speaker: Emily
transcript.text: It absolutely does. Thanks again, Sydney, and have a great rest of your day!

transcript.speaker: Sydney
transcript.text: You too. Bye.
